canonical_explanation.text: Buoyancy is the upward force exerted by a fluid on any object placed in it. This upward force is called upthrust or buoyant force. Archimedes' principle states that when an object is immersed in a fluid, it experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. An object floats if its density is less than the density of the fluid, and sinks if its density is greater. Ships float because they are designed to displace a large volume of water, making their average density less than water. Submarines can change their density by adjusting the amount of water in their ballast tanks.
rules: Buoyancy is the upward force exerted by a fluid on an immersed object.
Archimedes' principle: Upthrust equals weight of displaced fluid
Object floats if: Density of object < Density of fluid
Object sinks if: Density of object > Density of fluid
Object remains suspended if: Density of object = Density of fluid
Buoyant force depends on volume of object submerged and density of fluid
Ships float due to their hollow design creating low average density
Hydrometers use the principle of floatation to measure liquid density

questions.question_text: The upward force exerted by a fluid on an immersed object is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The upward force exerted by a fluid (like water or air) on an immersed object is called buoyancy. This force acts to push the object upwards, which is why objects can float in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upward force is not gravity, which is the downward pull of the Earth. It's also not friction, which is the force that opposes the motion of an object, or tension, which is the force that pulls an object in opposite directions. The correct term for the upward force on an immersed object is buoyancy, as defined by Archimedes' principle.

questions.question_text: According to Archimedes' principle, the upthrust on an object equals:
questions.explanation_correct: According to Archimedes' principle, the upward force or upthrust experienced by an object immersed in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This means the upthrust is directly proportional to the weight (or volume) of the fluid displaced, not the weight or volume of the object itself.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upthrust is not equal to the weight of the object, as the weight of the object is a force acting downwards due to gravity. The upthrust is also not equal to the volume of the object or the density of the fluid, as it is specifically the weight of the fluid displaced that determines the upward buoyant force.

questions.question_text: An object will float in a liquid if:

options.text: Its density is greater than the liquid
Its density is less than the liquid
Its weight is more than the liquid
Its volume is less than the liquid

questions.explanation_correct: An object will float in a liquid if its density is less than the density of the liquid. This is because the buoyant force acting on the object will be greater than the weight of the object, causing it to float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object will not float if its density is greater than the density of the liquid. In this case, the weight of the object will be greater than the buoyant force, causing it to sink. The object's weight and volume are not the only factors that determine whether it will float or sink - the density of the object compared to the density of the liquid is the key factor.

questions.question_text: In which direction does the buoyant force act?
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force acts in the upward direction because it is the force exerted by the fluid (such as water or air) on the object, and this force pushes the object upwards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not act in the downward, sideways, or in all directions. It acts only in the upward direction, perpendicular to the surface of the object. This is because the buoyant force is the result of the pressure differences in the fluid, which create an upward push on the object.

questions.question_text: Why does a steel ship float on water while a steel nail sinks?

options.text: Ship is made of lighter steel
Ship has a hollow design with low average density

questions.explanation_correct: The ship has a hollow design, which means it has a large volume but relatively low average density. This allows the ship to displace a large amount of water, creating an upward buoyant force that is greater than the weight of the ship, causing it to float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The steel ship floats because its average density is less than the density of water, due to its hollow design. The steel nail sinks because its density is greater than the density of water, even though both are made of the same material (steel). The ship's large volume and low average density is what allows it to float, not because it is made of lighter steel or because it is painted.

questions.question_text: How does a submarine sink and rise in water?

options.text: By adjusting water in ballast tanks

questions.explanation_correct: A submarine can sink and rise in water by adjusting the amount of water in its ballast tanks. When the submarine takes in water, it becomes heavier and sinks. When it expels the water, it becomes lighter and rises back up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Submarines do not change their shape to sink and rise. They also do not change the density of the water around them. Propellers are used to move the submarine forward and backward, but they do not change the submarine's buoyancy to make it sink or rise. The key is adjusting the amount of water in the ballast tanks to control the submarine's overall density and buoyancy.

questions.question_text: A block of wood weighs 50 N in air. When floating in water, the upthrust on it is:
questions.explanation_correct: The upthrust on the block of wood when it is floating in water is equal to the weight of the wood in air, which is 50 N. This is because the buoyant force on the wood is equal to the weight of the water displaced by the wood, which is the same as the weight of the wood in air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upthrust on the block of wood when it is floating in water is not less than 50 N, nor is it more than 50 N. When an object floats, the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the object in air. This is because the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, which is the same as the weight of the object in air.

questions.question_text: Which instrument uses the principle of floatation to measure liquid density?
questions.explanation_correct: A hydrometer uses the principle of floatation to measure the density of a liquid. When the hydrometer is placed in a liquid, it floats due to the buoyant force acting on it, and the depth it sinks depends on the density of the liquid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer, barometer, and ammeter do not use the principle of floatation to measure liquid density. A thermometer measures temperature, a barometer measures atmospheric pressure, and an ammeter measures electric current. Only a hydrometer, which is a special instrument designed to measure the density of liquids, uses the principle of floatation to determine the density.

questions.question_text: An ice cube floats with 90% of its volume submerged in water. What is the density of ice?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 0.9 g/cm³. This is because when an ice cube floats in water, 90% of its volume is submerged. According to Archimedes' principle, the buoyant force on the ice cube is equal to the weight of the water displaced, which is 90% of the volume of the ice cube. Since the density of water is 1 g/cm³, the density of the ice cube must be 0.9 g/cm³ to allow it to float with 90% of its volume submerged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) 0.9 g/cm³. The other options are incorrect because they do not match the density of ice required for the given scenario. Option B) 1.0 g/cm³ is the density of water, not ice. Option C) 0.1 g/cm³ is too low to represent the density of ice. Option D) 1.1 g/cm³ is too high for the density of ice.

questions.question_text: A body weighs 100 N in air and 60 N when fully immersed in water. The buoyant force acting on it is:
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force acting on the body is 40 N. This is because the weight of the body in air is 100 N, but when immersed in water, the buoyant force (upward force) reduces its apparent weight to 60 N. The difference between these two weights is the buoyant force, which is 40 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force is not 100 N, 60 N, or 160 N. The buoyant force is the difference between the weight of the body in air and its weight when immersed in water, which is 40 N. This is because the buoyant force acts upwards and reduces the apparent weight of the object in the fluid.

questions.question_text: Buoyant force acts in the downward direction.
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force acts in the upward direction, not downward. This is because the fluid (such as water or air) exerts an upward force on the object, pushing it up. This upward force is the buoyant force, as described by Archimedes' principle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not act in the downward direction. The buoyant force is the upward force exerted by a fluid on an object placed in it. This upward force is caused by the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the object, as described by Archimedes' principle. The buoyant force always acts in the upward direction, opposing the downward force of gravity.

questions.question_text: Archimedes' principle applies to both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, Archimedes' principle applies to both liquids and gases. The principle states that when an object is immersed in a fluid (which can be a liquid or a gas), it experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This is true for both liquids and gases, as they both exert a buoyant force on objects placed in them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Archimedes' principle does not apply only to liquids. It applies to both liquids and gases. When an object is placed in a fluid, whether it is a liquid or a gas, it experiences an upward buoyant force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced. This is true for both liquids like water and gases like air. The principle holds true for any fluid, not just liquids.

questions.question_text: A floating object displaces a volume of liquid equal to its own weight.
questions.explanation_correct: A floating object displaces a volume of liquid equal to its own weight because of Archimedes' principle. This principle states that the upward buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. Therefore, the volume of liquid displaced is directly related to the weight of the floating object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. When an object floats, it pushes down on the liquid below it, and the liquid pushes up on the object with an equal force. This upward force, called the buoyant force, is equal to the weight of the liquid displaced by the object. So a floating object displaces a volume of liquid equal to its own weight.

questions.question_text: Hot air balloons rise because hot air is denser than cold air.
questions.explanation_correct: Hot air balloons rise because hot air is less dense than cold air. The hot air inside the balloon is heated, causing it to become less dense than the surrounding cold air. This difference in density creates an upward buoyant force that lifts the balloon upward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'Hot air balloons rise because hot air is denser than cold air' is incorrect. Hot air is actually less dense than cold air, and this difference in density is the reason why hot air balloons rise. The hot air inside the balloon is heated, making it less dense than the surrounding cold air, and the resulting upward buoyant force lifts the balloon upwards.

questions.question_text: The upward force exerted by a fluid on an object is called ___ or buoyant force.
questions.explanation_correct: The upward force exerted by a fluid on an object is called 'upthrust' or buoyant force. This is because the fluid (like water) pushes up on the object, creating an upward force that counteracts the object's downward weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upward force exerted by a fluid on an object is not called 'push' or 'lift'. The correct term is 'upthrust' or 'buoyant force'. Upthrust is the force that makes objects float in fluids like water or air.

questions.question_text: According to Archimedes' principle, upthrust equals the weight of ___ displaced.
questions.explanation_correct: According to Archimedes' principle, the upward force or upthrust on an object in a fluid is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This is because the fluid displaced has to be supported by the upward force, which is the buoyant force or upthrust.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'fluid'. The upthrust is not equal to the weight of the object itself, but rather the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This is because the buoyant force acts to support the weight of the fluid that the object displaces, not the weight of the object directly.

questions.question_text: A ___ is used to measure the density of liquids using the principle of floatation.
questions.explanation_correct: A hydrometer is used to measure the density of liquids using the principle of floatation. It is designed to float in the liquid, and the depth it sinks depends on the density of the liquid. This allows the density of the liquid to be read directly from the hydrometer scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer is not used to measure the density of liquids. A thermometer measures temperature, not density. The correct answer is a 'hydrometer', which is a device that uses the principle of floatation to measure the density of liquids. The hydrometer floats at a depth that depends on the density of the liquid, allowing the density to be read directly from the hydrometer scale.

questions.question_text: An object will float if its density is ___ than the density of the liquid.
questions.explanation_correct: An object will float if its density is less than the density of the liquid it is placed in. This is because the upward buoyant force on the object is greater than the downward force of gravity, causing the object to float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An object will not float if its density is greater than the density of the liquid. The object will sink because the downward force of gravity is greater than the upward buoyant force. The correct answer is 'less' - the object will float if its density is less than the density of the liquid.

questions.question_text: Arrange these objects by how much they would sink in water (most submerged first):
questions.explanation_correct: The objects are arranged from most submerged to least submerged based on their density. Iron has a higher density than water, so it will sink completely. Ice has a density slightly less than water, so it will partially sink. Cork has a much lower density than water, so it will float the highest on the water surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order is incorrect. Iron has the highest density and will sink completely, followed by ice which has a density slightly less than water, and cork which has a very low density and will float the highest. The order should be: Iron (sinks), Ice (density 0.9 g/cm³), Cork (density 0.2 g/cm³).

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to find buoyant force on an object:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is 'Weigh object in air', 'Weigh object in water', and then 'Calculate the difference in weights'. This is because we need to first find the weight of the object in air, then weigh it in water to find the buoyant force, and finally calculate the difference between the two weights to get the buoyant force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be 'Calculate the difference in weights', 'Weigh object in air', and 'Weigh object in water'. This is wrong because we cannot calculate the buoyant force without first finding the weight of the object in air and in water. We need these two measurements to then calculate the difference and find the buoyant force.

questions.question_text: Buoyancy is experienced by objects immersed in:
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyancy is experienced by objects immersed in both liquids and gases because the upward force, called the buoyant force, acts on the object due to the fluid (liquid or gas) it is placed in. This is because the fluid exerts an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, as per Archimedes' principle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Buoyancy is not just experienced in liquids or just in water. It is experienced in any fluid, which includes both liquids and gases. The buoyant force acts on the object due to the fluid it is placed in, not just water or liquids. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Who discovered the principle of buoyancy?
questions.explanation_correct: The principle of buoyancy was discovered by the ancient Greek mathematician and scientist Archimedes. He found that when an object is immersed in a fluid, it experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Archimedes. He discovered the principle of buoyancy, which states that when an object is immersed in a fluid, it experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object. This is known as Archimedes' principle. The other options, such as Newton, Galileo, and Einstein, were famous scientists, but they did not discover the principle of buoyancy.

questions.question_text: An object will remain suspended in a liquid if:

options.text: Its density equals the liquid density
Its density is greater than the liquid
Its density is less than the liquid

questions.explanation_correct: The object will remain suspended in the liquid if its density is equal to the density of the liquid. This is because the upward buoyant force acting on the object is equal to the weight of the object, and the net force on the object is zero, allowing it to remain suspended.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object will not remain suspended if its density is greater than or less than the density of the liquid. If its density is greater, the object will sink, and if its density is less, the object will float. The object will only remain suspended if its density is exactly equal to the density of the liquid, so that the upward buoyant force and the downward weight force cancel out.

questions.question_text: The apparent weight of an object in water is:
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent weight of an object in water is less than its actual weight because of the upward buoyant force acting on the object. This buoyant force, as described by Archimedes' principle, is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, which reduces the object's apparent weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The apparent weight of an object in water is not greater than its actual weight, as the buoyant force acting upwards on the object reduces its apparent weight. The apparent weight is also not equal to the actual weight, as the buoyant force counteracts a portion of the object's weight. Finally, the apparent weight is not always zero, as the object will only float if its density is less than the density of the fluid it is placed in.

questions.question_text: The buoyant force depends on:

options.text: Volume of the submerged part and density of fluid

questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force depends on the volume of the submerged part of the object and the density of the fluid. This is because the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, which is directly proportional to the volume of the submerged part and the density of the fluid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not depend on the mass, shape, or color of the object. It depends on the volume of the submerged part and the density of the fluid, as per Archimedes' principle. The mass, shape, and color of the object do not affect the buoyant force acting on it.

questions.question_text: A piece of wood floats in water. This means the density of wood is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a piece of wood floats in water, it means the density of the wood is less than the density of water, which is 1 g/cm³. Therefore, the correct answer is that the density of the wood is less than 1 g/cm³.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the density of the wood were greater than 1 g/cm³, it would sink in water. If the density of the wood were equal to 1 g/cm³, it would just barely float on the surface. And if the density of the wood were zero, it would float extremely high on the water, which is not the case for a normal piece of wood. So, the correct answer is that the density of the wood is less than 1 g/cm³, which allows it to float in water.

questions.question_text: When you push a ball underwater and release it, the ball rises up because:

options.text: The ball wants to escape water
The buoyant force is greater than the weight of the ball
The ball becomes lighter in water

questions.explanation_correct: The ball rises up when released because the buoyant force acting on it is greater than its weight. The buoyant force pushes the ball upwards, overcoming the downward force of gravity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct. When you push a ball underwater, the buoyant force from the water pushes up on the ball. This upward buoyant force is greater than the weight of the ball, so the ball rises back up to the surface. The ball does not want to escape the water, nor does it become lighter in water. The water does not push the ball down, but rather provides the upward buoyant force that makes the ball rise up.

questions.question_text: An object displaces 500 cm³ of water when fully submerged. The upthrust on it is: (Density of water = 1 g/cm³)
questions.explanation_correct: The upthrust on the object is 500 gf because the upthrust is equal to the weight of the fluid (water) displaced, which is 500 cm³ of water with a density of 1 g/cm³. So the upthrust is 500 cm³ x 1 g/cm³ = 500 gf.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upthrust is not 5 gf, 5000 gf, or 50 gf. These options are incorrect because the upthrust is directly related to the volume of water displaced, which is 500 cm³ in this case. The correct upthrust is 500 gf, as calculated from the volume of water displaced and the density of water.

questions.question_text: A body floats with 2/3 of its volume outside water. The density of the body is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 0.33 g/cm³. When a body floats with 2/3 of its volume outside the water, the density of the body must be less than the density of water (1 g/cm³), as the buoyant force supports 1/3 of the body's volume inside the water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) 0.33 g/cm³. This is because when a body floats with 2/3 of its volume outside the water, the density of the body must be less than the density of water (1 g/cm³). This is to ensure that the buoyant force supports 1/3 of the body's volume inside the water. The other options, A) 0.67 g/cm³, C) 1.5 g/cm³, and D) 2 g/cm³, are all greater than the density of water, so the body would sink in these cases.

questions.question_text: Why is it easier to lift a heavy stone inside water than outside?

options.text: Water reduces the mass of the stone
Water provides an upward buoyant force

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. When an object is placed in a fluid like water, it experiences an upward buoyant force that reduces the net force acting on it. This makes the object appear lighter, making it easier to lift the heavy stone inside water compared to outside.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Option A is wrong because water does not reduce the mass of the stone - the stone's mass remains the same. Option C is incorrect because the stone does not dissolve in water. Option D is wrong because gravity does not change inside water.

questions.question_text: A ship sinks deeper in fresh water than in sea water because:

options.text: Sea water is denser than fresh water

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. Sea water is denser than fresh water, so a ship will float higher in sea water and sink deeper in fresh water. This is because the buoyant force exerted by the fluid (Archimedes' principle) is greater in denser sea water, causing the ship to float higher.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. Fresh water temperature (A) and ship rusting (D) do not affect how deep a ship sinks. While fresh water has slightly lower pressure than sea water (C), this difference is not significant enough to make the ship sink deeper in fresh water. The key reason a ship sinks deeper in fresh water is that fresh water is less dense than sea water, resulting in a lower buoyant force.

questions.question_text: A stone weighs 50 N in air and 30 N in water. What is the volume of the stone? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 2000 cm³. This can be calculated using Archimedes' principle. The weight difference between the stone in air and in water is the buoyant force, which is equal to the weight of the displaced water. Using the formula for buoyant force, we can find the volume of the stone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the volume calculated using Archimedes' principle. The weight difference of 20 N between the stone in air and in water is the buoyant force, which is equal to the weight of the displaced water. Using the formula for buoyant force, we can calculate the volume of the stone to be 2000 cm³.

questions.question_text: An object floats in a liquid with 75% of its volume submerged. The ratio of densities of object to liquid is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 3:4. This is because when an object floats, the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced. Since 75% of the object's volume is submerged, the weight of the fluid displaced is 75% of the object's weight. Therefore, the ratio of the densities of the object to the liquid is 3:4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is not correct. For an object to float with 75% of its volume submerged, the ratio of the densities of the object to the liquid must be 3:4. This is because the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced, which is 75% of the object's weight. Therefore, the correct ratio of the densities is 3:4, not any of the other options.

questions.question_text: A solid cube of side 10 cm floats in water with 6 cm immersed. The weight of the cube is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 600 gf. This is because the weight of the cube is equal to the weight of the water displaced by the immersed part of the cube, which is 6 cm × 6 cm × 6 cm = 216 cubic cm. The weight of 216 cubic cm of water is 216 grams, which is equal to 600 gf.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) 600 gf. The weight of the cube is equal to the weight of the water displaced by the immersed part of the cube, which is 6 cm × 6 cm × 6 cm = 216 cubic cm. The weight of 216 cubic cm of water is 216 grams, which is equal to 600 gf. Options B) 400 gf, C) 1000 gf, and D) 60 gf are incorrect because they do not match the actual weight of the water displaced by the cube.

questions.question_text: The buoyant force on a fully submerged object depends on:

options.text: Volume of the object and density of fluid

questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force on a fully submerged object depends on the volume of the object and the density of the fluid it is submerged in, as stated by Archimedes' principle. The buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, which is determined by the object's volume and the fluid's density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not depend on the depth of submersion, weight, or mass of the object. The buoyant force is determined by the volume of the object and the density of the fluid it is submerged in. The deeper the object is submerged, the greater the volume of fluid displaced, and therefore the greater the buoyant force acting on the object.

questions.question_text: The Plimsoll line on ships indicates:

options.text: Safe loading limits in different waters

questions.explanation_correct: The Plimsoll line on ships indicates the safe loading limits in different waters. This line shows the maximum depth a ship can be safely loaded to, based on the type of water the ship is sailing in, to prevent the ship from sinking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Plimsoll line does not indicate the direction of travel, the speed of the ship, or the age of the ship. It is specifically used to show the safe loading limits for a ship based on the type of water it is sailing in, to ensure the ship does not become overloaded and sink.

questions.question_text: Which will float in water?
questions.explanation_correct: A wooden log will float in water because the average density of the wood is less than the density of water. This means the wooden log will experience an upward buoyant force that is greater than its weight, causing it to float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The iron nail, lead ball, and stone will all sink in water because their densities are greater than the density of water. This means they will experience a smaller upward buoyant force than their weights, causing them to sink.

questions.question_text: As an object sinks deeper in water, the buoyant force on it:
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force on an object remains the same as it sinks deeper in water. This is because the buoyant force is determined by the weight of the fluid displaced, which does not change as the object goes deeper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not decrease as the object sinks deeper. This is because the weight of the fluid displaced increases as the object goes deeper, which results in a greater upward buoyant force. The buoyant force also does not become zero, as an object will continue to experience an upward force as long as it is submerged in the fluid.

questions.question_text: A lactometer is used to check:

options.text: Purity of milk by measuring its density

questions.explanation_correct: A lactometer is used to measure the density of milk. The density of milk can tell us if it has been diluted with water, which would lower its density. This makes the lactometer a useful tool to check the purity of milk by measuring its density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A lactometer is not used to check the temperature, color, or taste of milk. It is specifically designed to measure the density of milk, which is an indicator of its purity. The density of pure milk is higher than the density of milk diluted with water, and the lactometer can detect this difference to tell if the milk is adulterated.

questions.question_text: The loss in weight of an object when immersed in a fluid equals:
questions.explanation_correct: The loss in weight of an object when immersed in a fluid equals the weight of the fluid displaced. This is because the buoyant force (upward force) acting on the object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced, as per Archimedes' principle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The loss in weight of an object when immersed in a fluid does not equal the weight of the object, its volume, or its mass. The loss in weight is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced, which is determined by the volume of the object and the density of the fluid. This is the key principle behind Archimedes' principle and understanding why objects float or sink.

questions.question_text: Buoyancy is a contact force.
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyancy is not a contact force. It is an upward force exerted by a fluid on an object immersed in it. This force acts on the object even if it is not in direct contact with the fluid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Buoyancy is often mistaken to be a contact force, but that is not the case. Buoyancy is an upward force that acts on an object due to the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the object when it is immersed in a fluid. This pressure difference creates an upward force, even if the object is not in direct contact with the fluid.

questions.question_text: A steel ball will float if made hollow and large enough.
questions.explanation_correct: A steel ball will float if made hollow and large enough because the average density of the hollow steel ball will be less than the density of water. According to Archimedes' principle, an object floats if its density is less than the density of the fluid it is placed in.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A solid steel ball would not float, even if made very large, because steel is denser than water. The density of the steel ball would still be greater than the density of water, causing it to sink. However, if the steel ball is made hollow, its average density can become less than the density of water, allowing it to float.

questions.question_text: The buoyant force on an object depends on the depth at which it is submerged.
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force on an object depends only on the volume of the object and the density of the fluid, not the depth at which it is submerged. Archimedes' principle states that the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, which is independent of the object's depth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that the buoyant force depends on the depth of the object. However, this is not true. The buoyant force is determined by the volume of the object and the density of the fluid, not the depth at which the object is placed. The depth of the object does not affect the buoyant force acting on it.

questions.question_text: Fish use their swim bladder to control their buoyancy.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Fish use their swim bladder to control their buoyancy. The swim bladder is an air-filled sac that allows fish to adjust their body density, enabling them to float or sink as needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Fish use their swim bladder, an air-filled sac in their body, to control their buoyancy. The swim bladder allows them to adjust their body density, making them more or less dense than the surrounding water, which helps them float or sink as needed. Some fish do not have swim bladders, but they can still control their buoyancy through other means, such as adjusting the water content in their bodies.

questions.question_text: If an object sinks in water, it will also sink in oil.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. If an object sinks in water, it will also sink in oil because the density of the object is greater than the density of the fluid, whether it's water or oil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Even though oil has a lower density compared to water, if an object sinks in water, it will also sink in oil. This is because the density of the object itself is greater than the density of both water and oil, so the object will sink in either fluid.

questions.question_text: For a floating object, the weight of the object equals the weight of the liquid displaced.
questions.explanation_correct: The weight of a floating object is equal to the weight of the liquid displaced, which is the buoyant force acting on the object. This is known as Archimedes' principle, which states that the upward buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The weight of the object is not equal to the weight of the liquid displaced. The weight of the liquid displaced is equal to the buoyant force, which is the upward force that keeps the object floating. The weight of the object is supported by this buoyant force, but it is not the same as the weight of the liquid displaced.

questions.question_text: Archimedes discovered the principle of buoyancy while taking a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Archimedes discovered the principle of buoyancy while taking a bath. As he got into the bathtub, he noticed the water level rise, and realized that the upward force pushing against his body was equal to the weight of the water that was displaced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'bath'. Archimedes did not discover the principle of buoyancy while doing some other activity, like swimming or studying. He made this important discovery while relaxing in his bathtub, when he noticed the water level rise as he got in, and realized the connection between the upward force and the displaced water.

questions.question_text: The apparent weight of an object in water equals its actual weight minus the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The apparent weight of an object in water is less than its actual weight because of the upthrust or buoyant force acting on the object. The upthrust is an upward force exerted by the water on the object, which reduces the weight that we measure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The apparent weight of an object in water is not the actual weight minus the object's weight. The correct answer is 'upthrust'. The upthrust is the upward force exerted by the water on the object, which reduces the weight that we measure. This is in accordance with Archimedes' principle.

questions.question_text: An object will sink if its density is ___ than the liquid density.
questions.explanation_correct: An object will sink if its density is greater than the density of the liquid it is placed in. This is because the upward buoyant force exerted by the liquid is not strong enough to keep the denser object afloat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'greater'. An object will sink if its density is greater than the liquid density. This is because the buoyant force acting upwards on the object is not strong enough to counteract the object's weight, causing it to sink. If the object's density is less than the liquid's density, the buoyant force will be greater, allowing the object to float.

questions.question_text: Submarines use ___ tanks to control their buoyancy.
questions.explanation_correct: Submarines use ballast tanks to control their buoyancy. Ballast tanks are compartments that can be filled with water or air to change the overall density of the submarine, allowing it to sink or float as needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Submarines do not use springs or air pumps to control their buoyancy. The correct answer is 'ballast tanks'. Ballast tanks are compartments that can be filled with water or air, allowing the submarine to change its density and control whether it sinks or floats in the water.

questions.question_text: When an object ___, the upthrust equals the weight of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: When an object floats, the upthrust (buoyant force) on the object is equal to the weight of the object. This is because the object is displacing a volume of fluid equal to its own volume, and the weight of this displaced fluid is equal to the weight of the object, causing the object to float.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When an object sinks, the upthrust is not equal to the weight of the object. The upthrust is always equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, but when the object sinks, its weight is greater than the upthrust, causing it to sink. For an object to float, the upthrust must be equal to the weight of the object.

questions.question_text: Upthrust = Volume submerged × ___ of fluid × g.
questions.explanation_correct: The formula for upthrust (buoyant force) is Upthrust = Volume submerged × density of fluid × g. This is because the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, as per Archimedes' principle. The density of the fluid is a key factor in determining the upthrust.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'density'. The formula for upthrust (buoyant force) is Upthrust = Volume submerged × density of fluid × g. This is because the buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by the object, as per Archimedes' principle. The density of the fluid, not the weight of the fluid, is the key factor in determining the upthrust.

questions.question_text: A ___ is used to measure the density or purity of milk.
questions.explanation_correct: A lactometer is used to measure the density or purity of milk. This is because milk contains substances like fat and proteins, and a lactometer can detect how dense the milk is compared to pure water, which helps determine its quality and purity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'lactometer'. A lactometer is a special instrument used to measure the density or purity of milk. It works by detecting how dense the milk is compared to pure water, which allows you to tell if the milk has the right amount of fat and other substances. This is important for ensuring the milk is of good quality before it is sold or used.

questions.question_text: The centre of buoyancy is the ___ of the displaced fluid.
questions.explanation_correct: The centre of buoyancy is the centre of gravity of the displaced fluid. This is because the upward buoyant force acts at the centre of gravity of the displaced fluid, which is the point where the weight of the displaced fluid is concentrated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'centre of gravity'. The centre of buoyancy is not the centre of mass of the object, but the centre of gravity of the fluid displaced by the object. The centre of gravity of the displaced fluid is the point where the weight of the displaced fluid is concentrated, and this is where the upward buoyant force acts on the object.

questions.question_text: Arrange these materials in order of increasing tendency to float in water:
questions.explanation_correct: The order of increasing tendency to float in water is Stone, Wood, Plastic ball (hollow). This is because the density of a stone is higher than water, so it sinks. The density of wood is less than water, so it floats. The plastic ball is hollow, so its average density is even lower than wood, making it float more easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Plastic ball (hollow), Wood, Stone. This is wrong because the plastic ball, being hollow, has the lowest density and so floats the best. Wood has a higher density than the plastic ball but lower than stone, so it floats better than stone. Stone has the highest density and will sink the fastest in water.

questions.question_text: Arrange these in order of increasing buoyant force (same object in different liquids):
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force is greater in liquids with higher density, so the order of increasing buoyant force is: Object in oil (least dense), Object in water, Object in mercury (most dense).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Object in water, Object in oil, Object in mercury. This is wrong because the buoyant force depends on the density of the liquid - the denser the liquid, the greater the buoyant force acting on the object. Mercury is the densest of the three liquids, so the object would experience the greatest buoyant force when placed in mercury.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps for a submarine to surface:
ordering_items: Water is expelled from ballast tanks
Average density becomes less than water
correct_answer: Water is expelled from ballast tanks
Average density becomes less than water
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: 1) Water is expelled from ballast tanks, 2) Average density becomes less than water, 3) Submarine rises. This is because the submarine needs to get rid of the extra water in its ballast tanks first, which makes its average density lighter than water, allowing it to surface and rise up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order is: 1) Submarine rises, 2) Water is expelled from ballast tanks, 3) Average density becomes less than water. This is wrong because the submarine can't rise up until the water is first expelled from the ballast tanks, which then reduces the average density to be less than water, enabling the submarine to surface.

questions.question_text: Arrange these liquids so that the same object would float highest (most above surface) to lowest:
questions.explanation_correct: The object would float highest in mercury, followed by water, and lowest in oil. This is because the buoyant force is directly proportional to the density of the liquid. Mercury has the highest density, so it exerts the greatest upward force on the object, causing it to float the highest above the surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object would not float highest in oil, followed by water, and lowest in mercury. This is because mercury has the highest density, so it exerts the greatest upward force on the object, causing it to float the highest above the surface. Water has a lower density than mercury, so the object would float lower in water than in mercury. Oil has the lowest density, so the object would float the lowest in oil compared to the other two liquids.

questions.question_text: How does the buoyant force on a solid iron cube differ from the buoyant force on a solid aluminium cube of the same volume when both are fully submerged in water?

options.text: Iron cube experiences greater buoyant force because iron is heavier
Aluminium cube experiences greater buoyant force because it is lighter
Both experience the same buoyant force because the displaced water volume is the same
Neither experiences buoyant force because both are metals

questions.explanation_correct: Both cubes experience the same buoyant force when fully submerged because they have the same volume and therefore displace the same volume of water. Buoyant force depends on the volume of fluid displaced and the density of the fluid, not on the material or weight of the submerged object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force does not depend on how heavy or light the object is. It depends only on the volume of fluid displaced and the density of the fluid. Since both cubes have the same volume and are fully submerged in the same fluid (water), they displace the same volume of water and experience exactly the same buoyant force.

questions.question_text: How does the fraction of volume submerged differ when the same wooden block floats in water (density 1 g/cm cubed) compared to mercury (density 13.6 g/cm cubed)?

options.text: It is submerged more in mercury because mercury pushes harder
It is submerged more in water because water is less dense than mercury
Equal fraction is submerged in both liquids
It sinks completely in both liquids

questions.explanation_correct: The wooden block is submerged more in water than in mercury. A floating object displaces fluid equal to its own weight. Since mercury is much denser than water, the block needs to displace only a very small volume of mercury to balance its weight, so it floats very high. In water, which is less dense, the block must displace a larger volume to balance the same weight, so a bigger fraction is submerged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fraction submerged depends on the ratio of the object's density to the fluid's density. In a denser fluid like mercury, a smaller fraction of the block needs to be submerged to displace enough fluid weight to support the block. In water, which is less dense, a greater fraction must be submerged. The block does not sink in either liquid because wood is less dense than both water and mercury.

questions.question_text: How does the apparent weight loss of a stone differ when it is fully immersed in water (density 1 g/cm cubed) compared to being fully immersed in salt solution (density 1.2 g/cm cubed)?

options.text: Loss is greater in water because water is pure
Loss is greater in salt solution because it is denser
Loss is the same in both because the stone volume is unchanged
There is no weight loss in either liquid

questions.explanation_correct: The apparent weight loss is greater in salt solution. Apparent weight loss equals the buoyant force, which is the weight of fluid displaced. Since the stone displaces the same volume in both liquids but salt solution is denser (1.2 g/cm cubed vs 1 g/cm cubed), the weight of displaced salt solution is greater, leading to a greater upthrust and greater apparent weight loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Though the stone has the same volume in both liquids, the buoyant force depends on both the volume displaced and the density of the fluid. A denser fluid exerts a greater buoyant force for the same displaced volume. Salt solution being denser than pure water therefore causes a greater apparent weight loss. Purity of water has nothing to do with the weight loss.

questions.question_text: How does the method of buoyancy control in a submarine differ from that in a fish?

options.text: Both use exactly the same mechanism of filling water
Submarine adjusts water in ballast tanks, while a fish adjusts gas in its swim bladder
Fish uses fins only, submarine uses ballast tanks only
Submarine changes the density of surrounding water, fish changes its own weight

questions.explanation_correct: A submarine controls buoyancy by taking in or expelling water from its ballast tanks, which changes its overall density. A fish, on the other hand, controls buoyancy by adjusting the amount of gas in its swim bladder. When the swim bladder inflates, the fish becomes less dense and rises; when it deflates, the fish becomes denser and sinks. Both ultimately change their average density, but through different mechanisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Though both submarine and fish control buoyancy by changing their average density, they use different mechanisms. The submarine fills or empties water from ballast tanks, while the fish adjusts gas volume in its swim bladder. Fins help the fish move but are not the primary mechanism for buoyancy control. Neither the submarine nor the fish changes the density of the surrounding water.

questions.question_text: How does the behaviour of an object whose density equals the liquid's density differ from one whose density is less than the liquid's density?

options.text: Both float on the surface of the liquid
The equal-density object remains suspended anywhere inside the liquid, while the less-dense object floats at the surface
The equal-density object sinks, while the less-dense object floats
Both remain suspended in the middle of the liquid

questions.explanation_correct: When an object's density equals the liquid's density, the buoyant force exactly equals the object's weight at any depth, so the object remains suspended wherever it is placed inside the liquid. When an object's density is less than the liquid's density, the buoyant force exceeds its weight when fully submerged, pushing it upward until it floats partially submerged at the surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two situations produce different results. An object with equal density to the liquid stays suspended at whatever depth it is placed because the net force on it is zero. An object less dense than the liquid cannot stay suspended inside the liquid. It rises to the surface and floats there with part of its volume above the liquid surface.

questions.question_text: A force acts upward on an object placed in a fluid, depends on the volume of the object submerged, and is equal to the weight of fluid displaced. This force is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The described force -- upward direction, dependent on the submerged volume, and equal to the weight of fluid displaced -- matches the definition of buoyant force or upthrust. This is exactly what Archimedes' principle describes. Gravitational force acts downward, frictional force opposes motion along surfaces, and magnetic force acts between magnetic materials, so none of those fit these characteristics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gravitational force acts downward, not upward, and does not depend on fluid displacement. Frictional force opposes motion along a surface. Magnetic force acts between magnets or magnetic materials. Only buoyant force (upthrust) acts upward on an immersed object, depends on the submerged volume, and equals the weight of fluid displaced, as described by Archimedes' principle.

questions.question_text: An object has a density of 0.85 g/cm cubed and is placed in water (density 1.0 g/cm cubed). Based on these values, the object should be classified as one that:

options.text: Floats partially submerged at the surface
Remains suspended in the middle of the water

questions.explanation_correct: Since the object's density (0.85 g/cm cubed) is less than the density of water (1.0 g/cm cubed), the buoyant force when fully submerged would exceed the object's weight. The object therefore rises to the surface and floats there, partially submerged. About 85% of its volume would be submerged since the fraction submerged equals the ratio of object density to liquid density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An object sinks only when its density is greater than the liquid's density. It remains suspended only when the densities are exactly equal. Since 0.85 g/cm cubed is less than 1.0 g/cm cubed, the object floats partially submerged at the surface. Dissolving is a chemical process unrelated to density and buoyancy.

questions.question_text: An instrument floats in a liquid and sinks deeper when the liquid is diluted with water. It is calibrated with a scale to give readings directly. This instrument should be classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The described instrument floats in a liquid, changes its depth based on the liquid's density, and has a calibrated scale for direct readings. These are the defining characteristics of a hydrometer, which works on the principle of floatation to measure liquid density. A thermometer measures temperature, a barometer measures atmospheric pressure, and a voltmeter measures electric potential difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer measures temperature using thermal expansion, a barometer measures atmospheric pressure using a mercury column, and a voltmeter measures electrical potential difference. None of these float in a liquid to measure its density. The instrument described uses the principle of floatation, changing its depth depending on the density of the liquid, which is exactly how a hydrometer works.

questions.question_text: A body weighs 80 N in air, 50 N in water, and 60 N in another liquid. The upthrust in the other liquid should be classified as:

options.text: Greater than upthrust in water, since apparent weight is higher
Less than upthrust in water, since the apparent weight in the other liquid is more than in water
Zero, since the body does not float

questions.explanation_correct: The upthrust in water is 80 - 50 = 30 N, while the upthrust in the other liquid is 80 - 60 = 20 N. Since 20 N is less than 30 N, the upthrust in the other liquid is less than in water. This means the other liquid is less dense than water, so it provides a smaller buoyant force for the same submerged volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A higher apparent weight in a liquid means the upthrust is smaller, not larger. Upthrust = weight in air minus apparent weight in liquid. In water: 80 - 50 = 30 N. In the other liquid: 80 - 60 = 20 N. The upthrust is not zero because the body still experiences a buoyant force even though it does not float. The other liquid is less dense than water, so it provides less upthrust.

questions.question_text: Riya is doing an experiment in her school lab. She hangs a metal block from a spring balance, which reads 4.5 N in air. She then lowers the block into a beaker of water and notices the reading drops to 3.0 N. What is the buoyant force acting on the metal block?
questions.explanation_correct: The buoyant force is the difference between the weight of the block in air and its apparent weight in water. Buoyant force = 4.5 N - 3.0 N = 1.5 N. This upward force from the water reduced the spring balance reading from 4.5 N to 3.0 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The buoyant force is not the weight in air (4.5 N) or the apparent weight in water (3.0 N). It is the difference between these two readings, which represents the upward push of the water on the block. Buoyant force = weight in air - apparent weight in water = 4.5 - 3.0 = 1.5 N. Adding the two values (7.5 N) has no physical meaning in this context.

questions.question_text: Amit drops a rubber ball (density 0.6 g/cm cubed) and a glass marble (density 2.5 g/cm cubed) into a bucket of water at home. What will he observe?

options.text: Both objects float on the surface
Both objects sink to the bottom
The rubber ball floats while the glass marble sinks
The glass marble floats while the rubber ball sinks

questions.explanation_correct: The rubber ball has a density of 0.6 g/cm cubed, which is less than water's density of 1.0 g/cm cubed, so it floats. The glass marble has a density of 2.5 g/cm cubed, which is greater than water's density, so it sinks. An object floats when its density is less than the liquid and sinks when its density is greater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Whether an object floats or sinks depends on comparing its density with that of the liquid. The rubber ball (density 0.6 g/cm cubed) is less dense than water (1.0 g/cm cubed) so it floats. The glass marble (density 2.5 g/cm cubed) is more dense than water so it sinks. They do not behave the same way because they have very different densities.

questions.question_text: Priya measures the weight of a stone as 2.5 N in air using a spring balance. She then immerses it fully in a measuring cylinder containing water and records that the water level rises from 100 mL to 150 mL. What is the upthrust on the stone? (Take density of water = 1 g/cm cubed and g = 10 m/s squared)
questions.explanation_correct: The volume of water displaced = 150 mL - 100 mL = 50 mL = 50 cm cubed. The mass of water displaced = volume times density = 50 times 1 = 50 g = 0.05 kg. The weight of water displaced (upthrust) = mass times g = 0.05 times 10 = 0.5 N. So the upthrust on the stone is 0.5 N.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upthrust equals the weight of water displaced, not the weight of the stone. The displaced volume is 150 - 100 = 50 cm cubed. Mass of displaced water = 50 g = 0.05 kg. Upthrust = 0.05 kg times 10 m/s squared = 0.5 N. Options A, C, and D arise from calculation errors such as using incorrect volume or forgetting to convert units properly.

questions.question_text: Rohan is at a swimming pool and notices he can float easily in the pool at a beach resort in Goa where the water is salty, but he struggles to float in the freshwater pool near his home in Pune. What is the best explanation for this?

options.text: The temperature of Goa's pool is higher, reducing gravity
Salt water is denser than fresh water, so it provides a greater buoyant force
Freshwater pools are always deeper, increasing pressure

questions.explanation_correct: Salt dissolved in water increases the water's density. According to Archimedes' principle, a denser fluid provides a greater buoyant force for the same volume displaced. In the salty pool, the upthrust on Rohan's body is greater than in fresh water, making it easier for him to float. This is the same reason why floating is easier in the Dead Sea, which has extremely salty water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature does not reduce gravity, and Rohan's weight does not change between cities. Pool depth affects pressure at the bottom but does not change the buoyant force on a body at the surface. The correct explanation is that salt water is denser than fresh water, so it exerts a greater buoyant force on the same body, making it easier to float.

questions.question_text: Meera places a solid cube of side 10 cm in water. She observes that exactly 7 cm of the cube is below the water surface. What is the density of the material of the cube? (Density of water = 1 g/cm cubed)
questions.explanation_correct: For a floating object, the fraction of volume submerged equals the ratio of the object's density to the liquid's density. The fraction submerged = 7/10 = 0.7. Therefore, density of cube / density of water = 0.7, so the density of the cube = 0.7 times 1.0 = 0.7 g/cm cubed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The density of the cube is found using the law of floatation: fraction submerged = density of object / density of liquid. Since 7 out of 10 cm is submerged, the fraction is 0.7. Multiplying by the density of water (1.0 g/cm cubed) gives 0.7 g/cm cubed. Option A (0.3) incorrectly uses the part above water. Option C (1.0) would mean the cube is fully submerged but suspended. Option D (1.3) would mean the cube sinks.

questions.question_text: Which of the following does NOT affect the buoyant force on a fully submerged object?
questions.explanation_correct: Buoyant force = volume of object submerged times density of fluid times g. The mass (or weight) of the object itself does not appear in this formula. Two objects of different masses but the same volume, submerged in the same fluid, will experience exactly the same buoyant force. The mass of the object determines whether it sinks or floats, but it does not determine the magnitude of the buoyant force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volume of the object determines how much fluid is displaced. Density of the fluid determines the weight of each unit volume of displaced fluid. Acceleration due to gravity (g) converts displaced mass to displaced weight. All three directly appear in the buoyant force formula. However, the mass of the object does not affect the buoyant force -- it only determines whether the object will sink, float, or remain suspended.

questions.question_text: Which of the following objects seems like it should sink in water but actually floats?
questions.explanation_correct: A large steel ship is made of steel, which is much denser than water (about 7.8 g/cm cubed). It seems like it should sink, but its hollow design encloses a large volume of air, making the ship's average density much less than water's density. This is why a massive steel ship floats, while a small solid steel nail sinks. The other objects -- solid iron ball, lead weight, and copper coin -- are all solid metals denser than water that genuinely sink.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A solid iron ball, a lead weight, and a copper coin are all solid pieces of metal denser than water, so they truly do sink. The ship is the exception because, despite being made of steel (denser than water), its hollow structure with air inside gives it a very low average density, allowing it to float. This demonstrates that shape and design, not just material, determine whether an object floats.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about buoyant force is NOT correct?

options.text: Buoyant force acts in the upward direction
Buoyant force equals the weight of fluid displaced
Buoyant force increases with the depth of a fully submerged object
Buoyant force depends on the density of the fluid

questions.explanation_correct: Statement C is NOT correct. For a fully submerged object, the buoyant force remains constant regardless of depth. This is a common misconception. The buoyant force depends on the volume of the object and the density of the fluid, not on how deep the object is. While pressure increases with depth, the pressure difference between the top and bottom of the object remains the same, so the net upward buoyant force stays constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statements A, B, and D are all correct. Buoyant force indeed acts upward, equals the weight of displaced fluid (Archimedes' principle), and depends on fluid density. Statement C is the incorrect one because the buoyant force on a fully submerged object does not change with depth. Though pressure increases with depth, the pressure difference across the object stays the same.

questions.question_text: Why is a hydrometer designed with a heavy bulb at the bottom and a thin graduated stem at the top?

options.text: The heavy bottom keeps it upright, and the thin stem gives sensitive readings for small density changes
To make it float sideways in the liquid
To prevent it from floating and keep it submerged

questions.explanation_correct: The heavy bulb at the bottom acts as ballast, keeping the hydrometer floating upright and stable. The thin graduated stem at the top means that even a small change in liquid density causes a noticeable change in the depth to which the hydrometer sinks, making the readings more sensitive and precise. This design is essential for accurately measuring small differences in liquid density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The design of the hydrometer is functional, not decorative. The heavy bottom provides stability so it floats vertically, not sideways. The hydrometer is meant to float partially submerged, not stay fully submerged. The thin stem provides sensitivity because a small change in density causes a large change in the position of the liquid level on the stem.

questions.question_text: Why does a person float more easily when they spread their arms and legs wide while lying on their back in water?

options.text: Because spreading out reduces the person's weight
Because spreading out improves rotational stability and keeps the lungs (the most buoyant part) near the surface, preventing dense legs from dragging the body down
Because the person's density decreases when they spread out
Because gravity acts less on a spread-out body

questions.explanation_correct: When a person spreads their arms and legs while lying on their back, it improves rotational stability and prevents the body from rolling over. The spread position keeps the air-filled lungs (the most buoyant body part) at the water surface and distributes the denser parts (legs, arms) horizontally rather than letting them hang vertically and pull the body down. The person's weight, volume, and density remain exactly the same — it is the improved stability and body orientation that makes floating easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The person's weight does not change when they spread out, and gravity does not change with body position. The person's density also remains the same — spreading out does not alter the ratio of mass to volume. The real reason is that spreading improves stability and keeps the buoyant chest region at the surface while preventing dense limbs from sinking vertically.

questions.question_text: Why does the apparent weight of an object decrease when immersed in a fluid, even though gravity has not changed?

options.text: Because the fluid absorbs some of the object's mass
Because the upward buoyant force partially counteracts the downward gravitational force, reducing the net downward force measured
Because the object becomes smaller inside the fluid

questions.explanation_correct: When an object is immersed in a fluid, the fluid exerts an upward buoyant force on it (equal to the weight of fluid displaced). The gravitational force still pulls the object downward with the same strength, but the buoyant force acts upward against it. A spring balance measures the net downward force, which is now the weight minus the buoyant force. This is why the reading decreases, giving a smaller apparent weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fluid does not absorb mass, the object does not shrink, and gravity does not weaken inside fluids. The actual weight of the object remains unchanged. What changes is the apparent weight, which is the net downward force. The upward buoyant force from the fluid partially cancels the downward gravitational force, so the measured (apparent) weight is less than the actual weight.
